Try to stub the classes you are testing. You can stub almost anything. If i=
t is not possible to stub classes wrap them. This can happen if you work wi=
th a class that is declared final.=A0  
My one advice would be not to actua=
lly create a server connection for unit tests. Your tests are supposed to b=
e simple. Try to create Fake server connection and pass them across. 

Unit=
 testing and refactoring should go hand in hand. If something is stopping y=
ou from unit testing, it would be a good time to start throwing away someth=
ing. There is a problem here too. To ensure your refactoring is right you s=
hould have unit tests but then that is the purpose why you started refactor=
ing. This is a chicken and egg problem. So start refactoring in small steps=
.=A0 

There are some good articles in developerWorks featuring Unit testin=
g. I have read the reviews of a book called "Working Effectively with Legac=
y Code"(http://www.amazon.com/Working-Effectively-Legacy-Robert-Martin/dp/0=
131177052/ref=3Dpd_bxgy_b_img_a) which seems to be useful. I did not get my=
 hands yet on this book.

I would suggest getting some hands on this book a=
nd something like this or taking a short training on agile training.

regar=
ds,
